newsitem.title: UNITED NATIONS: Richardson hopeful of "soft landing" in Zaire.
newsitem.headline: Richardson hopeful of "soft landing" in Zaire.

text.p: U.S. ambassador Bill Richardson said on Tuesday he was hopeful of a peaceful transition in Zaire as a result of talks scheduled this week between leaders of both warring sides.
Zairean President Mobutu Sese Seko and rebel leader Laurent Kabila were scheduled to meet on Wednesday.

Richarson, the U.S. top envoy to the United Nations, was speaking to reporters after briefing Security Council members on his own efforts during a recent visit to many of the countries involved in the Zaire crisis.
"I think it is very important that the international community, the U.N., support South Africa's mediation efforts to bring Kabila and Mobutu (to) face-to-face talks," Richardson said.

"I am encouraged with the potential of this meeting tomorrow, that it will lead to a soft landing, a peaceful transition," he said. "It's my view that South Africa deserves enormous credit, (President) Nelson Mandela in particular, whose moral force has brought these two Zairean leaders together twice now. And I think we have to hope for the best in this meeting that will happen, hopefully, tomorrow."

Richardson said that during two meeting with Kabila he had "pressed hard ... for a soft landing, for an inclusive transition, for an end to some of these disturbing humanitarian problems, and lastly for elections."
The United States had played the role of catalyst "and now it's up to the African parties to come together and resolve this problem," he said.

"But I am optimistic that there will be a soft landing and a peaceful, inclusive transition, mainly because of South Africa's very strong and effective and skilful efforts in the past two days at mediating this crisis," he added.
